column1: To help get that discussion started, the conference will feature  original research on monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, and the provision of liquidity, topics that are obviously highly relevant to the public policy missions of the Federal Reserve and other central banks.

Two contributions consider the implications of recent events for the conduct of monetary policy, both conventional and unconventional .2  Another paper addresses  the relationship between monetary aggregates an d financial stability.3  And several  papers investigate issues in the field of regulation and macroprudential supervision, including the design of an integrated framework for regulation, a proposal for dealing with systemically  important resolution issues in the rep urchase agreement  markets, and a r eview of the progress to date in reengineering the financial system .4                                                    2 See Mark Gertler and Peter Karadi (2012), “QE 1 vs.
